h3.a: Illinois Retired Teacher Association News Release

a.aria-label: Read more about Illinois Retired Teacher Association News Release

b.span: REMOTE LEARNING PLAN

Mt. Vernon High School Staff have developed a plan for Remote Learning Days as required by the Illinois State Board of Education (ISBE) as a result of the COVID19 Pandemic. Please address questions or concerns regarding the following guidelines to Mr. Rowdy Fatheree
. These guidelines are subject to change as Remote Learning Days may be modified or amended by ISBE.
Remote Learning Guidelines:
1. Remote Learning will allow students to continue learning when school is closed for an extended amount of time and as per ISBE guidelines.
2. Remote Learning Days count as attendance days for the purposes of the school calendar. Therefore during the term of a school closure the days wouldn’t be added to the end of the school calendar.
3. When Remote Learning Days are announced,

teachers will communicate with students using their google classroom and any other preferred methods of communication. Assignments will be posted online and other resources available to assist in completion of work to continue student learning. Students without internet access will be able to complete work through a learning packet, which is a hard copy of the assignment and then returned to the Attendance Office.
Teachers will be available to answer questions between 9:00 a.m.-2:00 p.m. during each Remote Learning Day.
Teachers will be checking their email, google classroom accounts and other approved communication platforms on a regular basis to assure that students' questions are addressed in a timely manner.
5. During Remote Learning Days students will have assignments for all their classes.

6. Teachers are aware that each student’s family may have special circumstances and that unexpected events may occur. If your family has a unique circumstance, please communicate with your teacher so we can work with you to solve the problem.
7. Students should reach out to their assigned School Counselor or Social Worker if they have special needs to address.
8. Students with IEPs and other special needs will have assignments in accordance with their individualized plans.
A. Students and/or their families will be contacted by their caseworker to assure all procedural safeguards are in place and that continuing of education takes place based upon the students IEP.
B. When a Remote Learning Day assignment plan cannot completely replicate an in-

session school day, efforts will be made to provide the support needed for particular students. For instance, if reading is a challenge for a student and the student has online access, the teacher may assign tasks on sites that will read text aloud.
For Parents/Guardians
• Parents/Guardians will be informed of the need for Remote Learning and the Remote Learning Plan is posted on the District’s website.
• Parents are welcome to contact the school with questions regarding any Remote Learning Plan.

• Parents/Guardians, along with teachers and students, are asked to remember that Remote Learning Days are designed to be flexible: if a student struggles with a concept or assignment and is unable to complete the work that day, parents should remind their son or daughter to communicate with the teacher as soon as possible on how to meet requirements.

• Parents/Guardians should contact teachers directly between 9 a.m. and 2 p.m. on an Remote Learning Day with any questions or concerns that may have regarding Remote Learning Day assignments. Teachers will respond within 24 hours.
For Teachers
In preparation for Remote Learning Days, teachers have been asked to:
• Familiarize students with desired procedures explaining the procedures to complete assignments.
• Provide a timely plan, posting work for the school day by 9:00 a.m.
• Plan for self-directed, independent learning with specific consideration for range and individual learning needs.
• Anticipate time requirements recognizing students learn at different paces, especially in an independent setting.
• Communicate with colleagues to ensure common expectations, communications, and protocols.
• Collaborate with service providers of diverse learners to differentiate assignments and/or expectations as needed.
During Remote Learning Days
All Teachers are expected to:
Check for parent communication emails throughout the Remote Learning Day from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m.
Continue your work as a team or individual on professional development topics.

Learning Packets: The District is currently working with Durham Bus Company to create a drop off and pick of hard copy assignments for students who don’t have internet access. Please continue to look for updates regarding this process on the District’s website, Facebook page and via email.
Approved: April 1, 2020
Jeffrey L. Fritchtntich
Superintendent
Mt. Vernon Township High School District #201

a.aria-label: Read more about Remote Learning Plan

p.br: Dear parents/guardians of students with disabilities,

div.p: We hope this letter finds you well as we continue to navigate through the COVID-19 pandemic and school closures.

This letter is written to discuss the provision of special education and related services for your child during mandated school closure. Our plan for providing instruction and related services to students with disabilities has two priorities:

ul.li: to focus on the health, safety, and welfare of our students and their families.
to make good faith efforts to provide appropriate, accommodated, and accessible services to students with disabilities in light of the current circumstances.

div.p:
With these priorities in mind, during the coming days, your child’s case manager will be reaching out to you to discuss a proposed, INDIVIDUALIZED Remote Learning Plan for providing remote learning for your child during our Remote Learning Days. We encourage you to engage in conversations about the following areas:
1. How are things going for you, your child(ren) and others in your household during this pandemic?
Please let your child’s case manager know if there are new circumstances that may impact your child’s ability to attend to his/her remote learning assignments. Some examples include: how your child has responded to the previously provided remote learning opportunities, a family member who is ill, a family member who lost their job, your child is providing supervision for siblings while you work, etc. We ask these questions so that we can put your child’s learning in the coming weeks into context.

br.span: 2. What specialized services and supports are necessary for your child as they learn at home?

Your child’s case manager will discuss the plan of support for your child and how that may look different while students are at home. Collaboration between parents and our school team is going to be a big part of making an appropriate plan.
3. What’s coming up for your child that we need to schedule or reschedule or discuss?

For some of you, we have open evaluations. Others have an annual review yet to be held this year. Now that our schedules have changed (and so have yours), we will discuss how we can manage open evaluations, annual reviews, etc. that have yet to be completed.

div.p: During the continued school closure, we want to work together with families to create INDIVIDUALIZED Remote Learning Plans for students with IEPs. Should you have any questions or concerns in the meantime, please do not hesitate to reach out to your child’s case manager.

a.aria-label: Read more about Individualized Remote Learning Plan

h3.a: Message from Mr. Jeff Fritchtnitch for April 1, 2020

p.br: Dear Mt. Vernon Township High School District #201 Students, Parents and Stakeholders:

div.p: I hope this finds your family healthy and safe as we continue to deal with these unprecedented times. Over the weekend and up to yesterday, the Illinois State Board of Education (ISBE) issued new guidance regarding how school will progress until Illinois schools are scheduled to reopen on May 1.

Since Tuesday, March 17, the ISBE has mandated that all missed school days be considered Act of God Days. All Illinois schools have now been instructed to transition from Act of God Days to Remote Learning Days. Based upon this new State mandate, MVTHS administration and department chairs have met to prepare the required Remote Learning Plan. This plan has been created and is being reviewed by the team and will be available for viewing later today on the District website and Facebook page.

Our school district understands and appreciates that Remote Learning is new for both our students and teachers. Therefore, the district plans to work collaboratively with our students and parents as we navigate Remote Learning and make it as successful as possible. We also realize that many of our families don't have internet access. We will continue to provide learning packets to students. We are working with Durham Transportation to create a drop off and pick up at bus stop sites throughout the district. Please continue to check email updates regarding that process. Should you have any questions with Remote Learning, please reach out to your child's teacher(s) or Mr. Fatheree as soon as possible.

As our nation continues to battle the COVID19 pandemic, Mt. Vernon Township High School District #201 will continue to do everything we can to support our students, academically and emotionally. Should your child need support, please contact your child's counselor or social worker via email. As new information becomes available, we will continue to provide updates in a timely manner. Please continue to adhere to the Governor's "Stay at home" order to help "Stop the Spread".

Jeff Fritchtnitch, Ed.S
Superintendent
MVTHS District #201

td.span: Projects or programs funded in whole or in part with Federal grant money must credit the Federal government for the Federal government's portion of the financial support. This citation informs the public that the use of Federal dollars. Staff development opportunities, resource purchases and personnel have been funded in whole or in part with Federal dollars.

td.p: 2. Ability to lift 50 pounds and ability to stand for long periods of time.
3. Prefer applicants who can establish and maintain good rapport with students, staff, and community
4. Current Illinois Food Service Sanitation Certificate or Food Handler Certificate preferred but not required.
5. Two year experience in a food service establishment or school cafeteria is preferred.
6. Ability to adapt to a fast paced environment and participate as part of a food service team.
7. Computer experience and retail/cash experience is desirable.
